titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: Twenty third Congress— Second Session
The Speaker John Bell of Tennessee, took the Chair at 12. O’Clock Noon, and called the house to order.
The roll was called over, and 188 members answered to their names
Twelve new members appeared to supply vacancies by death or resignation, and the Oath to support the Constitution of the United States, was administered to them by the Speaker—

Message from the Senate, announcing that they have formed a Quorum, and are ready to proceed to business; and had appointed a Committee on their part to inform the President that a Quorum of both Houses have assembled, and are ready to receive any communication from him—
M’Kinley of Alabama moves the Resolution of information to the President, and then a Message to the Senate—adopted—
Ward of New-York moves the Resolution that the members should be supplied with Newspapers equivalent to three daily.
Also that the daily hour of adjournment till otherwise ordered shall be 12. O’Clock—Noon.
House adjourned about 1. O’Clock.

Annual Message of the President of the United States delivered by his Secretary Donaldson, immediately after the Report of Mr M’Kinlay from the Committee on the part of the House, that the President would make a communication to the two Houses of Congress this day at twelve O’Clock—

It took the Clerk nearly an hour and a half to read the Message—which with the usual information relating to the present condition of public Affairs, contains long arguments upon the question in debate with France—against the U.S. Navy and against internal improvements.
Connor of North Carolina moves the reference of the Message to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union; and 10000 copies to be printed
Adjourn about 2. O’Clock.

Zadock Casey of Illinois, offers a Resolution, to wear crape 30 days, in honour of the memory of Charles Slade late a member of the house from that State, who died of the Cholera, on his way home after the close of the last Session, and pronounces a short Panegyric on the deceased—adopted.

Henry F. Janes of Vermont, with a similar Eulogy, offers a like Resolution in honour of Benjamin F. Deming a member from that State, who died on his way home, on the 11th. of July last—adopted— Mr Janes is the successor of Mr Deming in this house—
The House then adjourned before 1. O’Clock
Wardwell of New-York moves a long Resolution of enquiry to the Secretary of the Navy—to lie one day on the table
Grennell of Massachusetts moves a joint order for the choice of two Chaplains to interchange weekly— Adopted, not without opposition.
E Whittlesey moves the appointment of the standing Committees according to the Rules of the House
The Speaker presents to the House—the annual Finance Report of the Secretary of the Treasury—to lie on the table and ten thousand copies to be printed.
2. Statement of Receipts and Expenditures for 1833—
3. Reports of Register and Receiver of Land-Office at St Stephens Alabama— Act of 2. March 1829. §. 3
4. From the Clerk of the House— Annual Statement of Contingent Expenditures H.R.U.S. to 30. Novr 1834— See joint-Resolution of 1. March 1823.
5. Secretary of the Treasury— Estimates for the year 1835.
6. Treasurer U.S. Official Accounts for 1834.

Message P.U.S. to Congress—with a Letter from G. W. La Fayette and a copper-plate engraving of the Declaration of Independence, bequeathed by his father to Congress to be deposited in their Library— Referred to Committee of Foreign Affairs.
Joseph M. White Delegate from Florida, moves that the Message of P.U.S. to H.R.U.S. of 9. Decr 1833. with surveys of Canal Routes in Florida be printed for the use of the house— Carried.
Mann of New-York moves that when the House adjourns it shall be to Monday the 8th— Carried.
Adjourned after two O’Clock.
Standing Committees of the House announced Committee of Manufactures
R. I. Manning, sworn and takes his seat, in the place of James Blair of S.C deceased
F. W. Pickens of S.C. in place of G. M’Duffie
The States called over for Petitions

I presented the Petition of Thomas Aspinwall, Consul at London, for an act of Congress, authorising the allowance of certain charges in the Consulate, heretofore allowed by the Executive, but now denied.
Referred to the Committee of Foreign Relations.
E. Everett moves for a joint Committee on the library 3. on the part of the House
States called over for Resolutions.

Hawes of Kentucky moves the appointment of a Committee of one member from each State to inquire into the expediency of amending the Laws relating to the West-Point Academy on whether it would not comport with the public interests to abolish said institution—
After a debate of an hour, and the proposal of sundry amendments, all of which were rejected, the Resolution was adopted by yeas and nays—181 to 27.
Report received from the Secretary of the Treasury, enclosing a plan for the re-organization of that Department—
Referred at Wayne’s motion to a select Committee of nine, and order for printing 5000 copies of the Report.
Report from 1st. Comptroller of Balances more than 3. years due
Adjourned half past two.
Petitions called for

I presented the petition of Mrs Delia Tudor widow of William Tudor judge Advocate during the Revolutionary War for a Pension— It has been already three Sessions before the House— Referred to Committee on Revolutionary Pensions.
R. M. Johnson moves the printing of several Bills reported by the Committee on Military Affairs.

Chilton of Kentucky moves to discharge the Committee of the whole, from the Bill reported by him at the last Session for extending the Pension system to combatants against Indians from the Peace of 1783 to the Treaty of Greenville 1795—and to refer the Bill to the Committee of the whole on the Union— Adopted with an Amendment proposed by Wardwell—
Polk, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, moves the reference to that Committee of the Secretary of the Treasury’s Finance Report, and the Estimates of Appropriations for 1835.
Crockett of Tennessee moves that his bill about Land-titles in Tennessee, be made the order of the day for to-morrow week.
Motions for references, by R. M. Johnson and Beaty of Kentucky H. Johnson, R. Garland and P. Thomas of Louisiana—Hannegan Carr, and Ewing of Indiana, M’Kinley and Mardis of Alabama and many others.

Mason J. Y. of Virginia moves an instruction to the Committee of Foreign Relations to report a Bill to sell the Emperor of Morocco’s present of a Lion, and to dispose of the other presents deposited at the Department of State.
Wise moves to discharge the Committee of the whole from the Bill for erecting a Monument at York-town, and to make it the order of the day for Wednesday the 17th
Committee of the whole on the Union
Message of P.US. referred to the several Committees on the motion of Connor.

Clayton of Georgia moves an Amendment to instruct the Comee. of Foreign Relations to report against reprisals—and after debate withdraws the Amendment— Resolutions reported and agreed to by the House— Adjourned at 3.
Petitions, Memorials and Resolutions.

Clay from the Committee on public Lands, moves to make the Bill to provide for the reduction and graduation of public Lands the special order of the day, for the first Monday in January and that the Bill and report be printed.
Clayton moves the printing of 5000 extra copies of the report.

Gilmer from the Committee on Indian Affairs moves that the bill for the Establishment of the Western Territory, and about the Indian emigrants, be made the special order of the day, for the first Tuesday in January—and the bill and amendments to be printed.

Hubbard of N.H. moves a call on the Secretary of the Treasury for the correspondence between him and the President of the U.S. Bank, concerning the Branch Drafts, and the claim of the Bank for damages on the protested Bill of Exchange on France.

C. P. White of New-York moves that the Committee of Ways and Means be instructed to inquire into the expediency of providing by Law for the establishment of a branch of the U. S. Mint at N. York. Dunlap of Tennessee moves that the Committee on the Judiciary be instructed to inquire into the expediency of establishing a third judicial District in Tennessee, and of requiring the Judge of the District of East and West Tennessee, to hold one or more terms of said Court annually at the town of Jackson in said State.
Foster. T. F. of Georgia moves a call on P.U.S. for correspondence with the French Government, upon their refusal to provide for the execution of the Treaty of 4. July 1831.
Jarvis Leonard of Maine moves an enquiry by the Committee of Commerce, into the expediency of providing for a new registry enrollment and licensing of U.S. vessels.

Balloting for election of a Chaplain on the part of this House Four ballots— Polk nominates the Revd. Mr Copp— Wardwell of New-York nominates the Revd. Edward Smith— Several other nominations— Copp has 52— 55— 59 and 60 votes. Smith has 32— 39— 59— 99 votes and is elected.
Adjourn at half past three.
Hiester and Darlington— Persico in the Evening
Petitions, Memorials and Resolutions

White of New-York from the Committee on Naval Affairs reports a Bill amendatory to the Act in addition to the Acts for the organization of the Treasury, War and Navy Departments—twice read and referred to the Committee of the whole on the Union.
Hubbard’s Resolution calling on the Secretary of the Treasury for correspondence with the U.S. Bank—adopted without debate.

Foster’s Call on P.U.S. for copies of Correspondence with the French Government, coming up, was laid upon the table at his motion—he stated that he understood the Committee of foreign Affairs, had received a communication upon the subject from the Secretary of State, and were in expectation of receiving further documents

Jarvis of Maine moves an instruction to the Committee of Commerce, proposing that in the survey of the Coast the Latitudes and Longitudes of the Light-houses be ascertained and published, and no new Light-house be erected hereafter, till a report is made in respect to its public benefit, by the two Collectors and the Commander of the Navy-Yard nearest the proposed site as recommended in the Finance Report of the Secretary of the Treasury.
M’Kennan of Pennsylvania, offers a long Resolution, respecting the Cumberland road—to lie one day.
Deberry of North-Carolina moves an instruction of inquiry to extend the Pension Act of 7. June 1832 to artisans and wagoners.
Williams of North Carolina, moves a call to the Secretary of the Treasury for a return of Land Offices and Land districts and other information respecting the Sales of Public Lands—lies 1 day.
Allan, moves an inquiry for a grant of Township of Public Land to the University of Transylvania.
Clay. C. C moves a call on the Secretary of the Treasury for returns respecting the Sales of public Lands.
Johnson R. M. moves an instruction of inquiry to the District Committee to abolish imprisonment for debt— adopted—
Adjourned at 1/2 past two
The Resolution offered yesterday by M’Kennan respecting the Cumberland road, with a modification proposed by him was adopted

The Resolution yesterday offered by Lewis Williams of N.C. calling on the Secretary of the Treasury, a return of Land-Offices and Land Districts, was adopted with an Amendment offered by E. Whittlesey of Ohio.
On Motion of C. F. Mercer, so much of the President’s Annual Message as relates to Internal Improvement, was referred to the Committee on Roads and Canals.

Lewis of Alabama, moves an instruction of inquiry by the Committee of Public Lands, on three Resolutions for authorising entries of the public Lands—this gave rise to a debate which was arrested by E. Whittlesey of Ohio, calling for the Orders of the day; the consideration of private business.
Message from P.U.S. with documents relating to the Destruction of the Treasury building by fire
Letter from the Secretary of the Treasury with additional correspondence between the Secretary and the President of U.S Bank.
Order of the day private business
Mrs Decatur’s Bill on Patton’s motion, postponed to next Friday.
Bill for relief of D. Kilgore, on motion of Thomson postponed to same day
Committee of the whole; Ward of New-York in the Chair— Sixteen private Bills
Mrs Meade’s Bill and another set aside for this day.

Bill for the relief of Commodore Isaac Hull—much debated. It appropriates 6000 dollars for 3 years service as Navy Agent from 1829 to 1832 at the Navy Yard, at Washington— There was 600 dollars on other account— The 6000 dollars were struck out after long debate— Parker, Mann of New-York Pearce and Hardin for striking out Reed and E. Whittlesey against it.
Adjourned at 3. O’Clock over to Monday.
Petitions, Memorials and Resolutions.

Marshall of Kentucky, from the Committee on Revolutionary Claims, moves to discharge the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, from the consideration of the commutation Bill, and that it be referred again to the Committee on Revolutionary claims adopted.
Allan of Kentucky from the Committee on Territories, reports with an Amendment the Bill for the establishment of the Territory of Huron— Referred to the Committee of the whole on the Union

Lewis of Alabama’s Resolutions distributive of the Public Lands were taken up— Lewis Williams had moved their reference to the Committee of the whole— Mercer called for a division, to take the question on the first Resolution only—decided against the reference moved by Williams 72 to 73—on the other Resolutions the same decision.— The Resolutions themselves were then rejected—question twice taken—first time 33—second 37 affirmatives—
M’Kim moves that the Secretary of the Treasury, cause assays of all foreign gold and silver coins to be made, and returned to this House— Lies one day.
Thomas F. of Maryland, moves a call on the Secretary of the Treasury, for the official proceedings of the Government Directors of U.S. Bank. lies one day
Fulton of Virginia moves the printing of 5000 copies of the proceedings of the French House of Deputies, on the Treaty of indemnity of 4. July 1831.

Message from P.US. with a Letter from George W. La Fayette, in answer to the Letter from the President, communicating the Resolutions of Congress of the last Session, honorary to the memory of his father.
Supplemental Report from Secretary of the Treasury on the keeping and disbursing of the public Revenue—10000 copies to be printed.
Sundry Bills ordered to be engrossed and read the 3d. time.
Resolution to contract for four pictures in the Rotundo by four painters I moved to strike out four— Carried after much debate—
Franklin Insurance Company Policies.
Polk Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means—reports 3 Bills— 1. A Bill regulating the deposites of the public money of the United States in certain local banks—
2. A Bill to repeal the part of a former Statute, which directs the Bank of the United States, to perform the duties of Commissioners of Loans in the several States.
3. A Bill to authorize the Sale of the Bank Stock of the U.S. twice read, and made the special orders of the day, for the first Monday of January—
Polk reported also a Bill making appropriations, for the payment of the Pensions in 1835. read twice and referred to a Committee of the whole.
R. M. Johnson reported from the Military Committee
A Bill for the better organization of the corps of Topographical Engineers
A Bill providing for the gradual increase of the Corps of Engineers, and for other purpose— and
A Bill to authorize the appointment of additional paymaster read twice and referred.
Also a Bill for extending the time for issuing land-warrants to the Officers and Soldiers, of the revolutionary army—read twice, and ordered to be engrossed for a third reading.
Wayne, Chairman of the Committee of Foreign Relations reports a Bill to authorize the allowance of certain charges in the Accounts of the American Consul at London
and a bill to provide for the settlement of the claim of Mary O’Sullivan.
The Resolutions offered yesterday by M’Kim, and Thomas of Maryland and some others were adopted.
Clayton moved an Instruction of enquiry to the Committee of Ways and Means, to repeal the duties on locomotive engines and railway Car wheels, imported within two years to come
Denny moves the reference to the Committee of Manufactures
Some debate—arrested by the orders of the day.
Committee of the whole on the Bill to equalize the pay of the Army and Navy Officers— Briggs in the Chair— Comee. report progress.
adjourn at 3.
Severe influenza hoarse cough

Ashley of Missouri moved that two bills for extending the Cumberland road from Vandalia, Illinois to the Seat of Government of Missouri, be made the special order of the day for the 15th. of Jany. After some debate, adopt 74 to 50.
Pearce from the Committee of Commerce, reports a Bill making an appropriation for a Custom house at Newbern North-Carolina, read twice and Committed— N.B.
Clayton’s Resolution of Instruction to the Committee of Ways and Means, for remission of duties on locomotive engines, and rail-road car wheels within two years—

Debate on Denny’s motion to amend by making the reference to the Committee of Manufactures— Speeches from Dickerson of New Jersey, Mason of Virginia, Clayton, Denny, Speight, and Stewart, who moved to lay the Resolution on the Table— Clayton demands the yeas and nays, which stand 92 to 108
Chambers resumes the debate, for making the reference to the Committee of Manufactures; but the House soon passed to the Orders of the day.

Committee of the whole on the Union, Briggs in the Chair, on Watmough’s Bill, amended to equalize and graduate the pay of the Officers of the Navy— Harper’s motion to amend the first item of 5500 dollars, proposed for the pay of the Senior Captain commanding a squadron to 4500. debated by Watmough, Speight, Fillmore, Connor, Ward and especially by Sutherland, who made an eloquent democratic Speech, in favour of the Gunners, Carpenters and ordinary seamen.
Harper’s Amendment reducing 5500 to 4500 carried by a vote of 90 to 55.
Watmough then moves a series of Amendments to correspond with that adopted by the Committee.
Wise proposes an Amendment—after some discussion, the Committee rise and report progress—
The House order the printing of the Amendments proposed in Committee, and adjourned at 3.

Balie Peyton of Tennessee from the Committee of foreign Relations, reported a joint Resolution authorizing and requiring the President of the United States to cause the present of a Lion and two Horses from the Emperor of Morocco, to be sold and that the proceeds be put into the Treasury— Read twice, and ordered to be engrossed for a third reading— Peyton reports also that the Committee be discharged from further consideration of the remainder of the Resolution referred to them; which proposed to dispose of the other unconstitutional presents, deposited at the Department of State— adopted

Clayton’s Resolution of enquiry by the Committee of Ways and Means, for repealing the duties on loco-motive engines, and rail-road Car wheels, with rolled iron tires, axles, springs &c already imported, or to be imported within two years.

Long Speech from Chambers, for reference to the Committee of Manufactures; answered by Cambreleng who affirmed that such resolutions for these 40 years had always been referred to the Committee of Ways and Means— William Jackson of Massachusetts makes a Speech on the same side—to which Miller of Pennsylvania replies— Ewing begins, but Watmough calls for the order of the day.

Committee of the whole on the Union. Briggs in the Chair, on the amended Bill to equallize the pay of the Officers of the army and navy of the United States— Watmough’s Amendments proposed yesterday are discussed by him, Speight, Wise, Reed, Harper of Pennsylvania, and Mann of New-York— Wise moves amendments discarding all distinction for seniority among the Captains— Pearce speaks in favour of Boatswains, Gunners and Schoolmasters— On Wards Motion the Committee rise and report progress— Adjourn at 3.
Fulton introduced to me Mra member of the Senate of Virginia—and Clowney of S.C. introducedPickens, who comes in the place of M’Duffie

Hamer of Ohio, moves an instruction to the Committee on so much of the President’s Message as recommends an Amendment to the Constitution, in the mode of electing President and Vice-President, was referred, to provide that the election be made directly by the People, in districts— That the election in no event shall devolve upon Congress— And that no person who has been elected shall be eligible again—and that no member of Congress shall be appointable to any Office under the United States.

The Speaker presents the memorial of the recent Convention held at Baltimore from the States of Virginia, Maryland, Ohio and the District of Columbia praying a grant for carrying on the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal—on motion of C. F. Mercer ordered to be printed and referred to the Committee in charge of the Bill on that subject.

Clayton’s Resolution for repealing the duties on Locomotive Engines and Railway Car wheels, resumed, and Ewing of Indiana makes a short Speech in favour of the reference to the Committee of Ways and Means— Rencher of North-Carolina, inclines to the Committee most interested in the Tariff, and objects to all disturbance of the compromise— Beardsley moves to lay the Resolution on the Table, though he voted against it on Wednesday.

His object now is to foreclose an otherwise unavoidably protracted debate— Clayton replies to Rencher, Binney supports the reference to the Committee of Ways and Means— Dickerson renewed the motion to lay on the table, which after a short Speech from Burges is carried by yeas and nays 125 to 85.
Joint Resolution for selling the Lion and horses— I moved to strike out the words “and required”—adopted without opposition and the Resolution passed—

Private Business— Bill in favour of David Kilbourn, an American Canadian Spy— Speeches from Wardwell, Briggs and Burges for the grant—and from Whittlesey, Chilton, Burd against it— House adjourned at 3. over to Monday.
Bynum of North-Carolina moves a Call upon the Secretary of War for a Report on the progress, and amount of Appropriations of internal improvement in the State of North-Carolina
Allan of Kentucky offered a Resolution for a call on the Secretary of the Treasury for returns of Appropriations, for Fortifications, Lighthouses Pensions and Internal Improvements
Bill to authorize the Registers and Receivers of the Land-Offices to administer Oaths, and take fees for the service—

Lane of Indiana moves an Amendment, that they shall administer Oaths gratuitously— M’Carty of Indiana moves an Amendment that the fees for administering the Oaths shall be paid from the Treasury— This was rejected— I spoke a few words in favour of Lane’s Amendment, which was adopted, and the Bill passed to a third reading.
On motion of Connor, chairman of the Committee on the Post Office appointed at the last Session they have leave to sit during the sitting of the house—

Committee of the whole on the Bill for regulating the pay of the Officers of the Navy— Briggs in the chair— D. J. Pearce concluded the Speech he began last Thursday—supporting the amendment offered by Wise— Pearce’s speech ranges wide Vanderpoel makes an eloquent Speech in favour of the Navy. R. M. Johnson follows, and Sutherland— Wise withdraws his amendment and offers another increasing the pay of Boatswains, Gunners, Sailmakers and Carpenters, which was discussed, until upon taking a question, there was no Quorum voting—upon which the Committee rose, and the Chairman reported the fact, and at half past three the House adjourned—

Hubbard from the joint Committee on the Oration in honour of La Fayette told me they had agreed, if convenient to me, it should be delivered on Wednesday the 31st. instt.—to which I assented— He told me the Committee proposed to report to-morrow.

Polk, reports two Appropriation Bills, for the support of the Army—and for the Indian Department for the year 1835. and a resolution instructing the Committee of Indian Affairs to inquire into the expediency of providing by law for a clerk to be employed in the Office of Superintendent of Indian Affairs at St. Louis.— Bills twice read and referred to the Committee of the whole on the Union—

Hubbard from the joint Committee on the Resolution for the delivery of an Oration on the life and character of La Fayette reported a concurrent Resolution fixing the 31st. of this month at half past twelve O’Clock for that ceremony.— Read twice and ordered to be engrossed for a third reading to-morrow.

Mercer, from the Committee of Roads and Canals, moved a Call on the Secretary of War for a report of the expenditure made in the improvement of the Cumberland river, and the effect thereof, with any information in his possession as to the extent to which such improvement can be carried up the said river, and at what cost.

Beaty, moved a joint Resolution, for adjourning the two Houses from this day to the 29th. instt.— Polk moved to lay the Resolution on the table— Wardwell asked for the yeas and nays— Carried 150 to 28.— The Resolutions offered yesterday by Bynum and Allan of Kentucky were agreed to.
Lincoln moves a call on the President for information relating to negotiations concerning the Northeastern Boundary lies over a day—

Foster called up his Resolution, calling on the President for Documents relating to the Negotiation with the French Government but at the request of Wayne to allow another Meeting of the Committee of Foreign Relations, withdraws his Motion. Bill to authorise the Registers and Receivers of the Land Offices to administer Oaths, was read a third time and passed—
The Bill regulating the pay of Naval Officers, passed in Committee of the whole on the Union, after much debate was reported to the House, and ordered to be printed.

The Resolution fixing the 31st. instt. for the delivery of the Oration upon the Life and character of La Fayette—had been ordered yesterday to be engrossed for a third reading. The Speaker this morning said it was not a joint, but a concurrent Resolution, and did not require three readings—he should therefore consider it as passed, and send it for concurrence to the Senate—

L. Lincoln’s Call upon the President, for information respecting the State of the Negotiation with the British Government concerning the Northeastern boundary, was opposed by Gorham Parks of Maine, who professed perfect indifference whether it should pass or not—but objected specially to the latter part of it— He considered it as an officious intrusion of a member from Massachusetts in the affairs of Maine, and as implying a censure upon the members from that State— He cast many reflections upon the State of Massachusetts for her supposed ill treatment of Maine— He is answered by Evans, who exposes the tergiversations and jugglery of the ruling party in Maine, upon this subject; in all which Parks himself has been a prominent actor— T. F. Foster of Georgia, makes a smart nullification Speech. Lincoln replies conclusively to the objections of Parks— Smith of Maine, opposes the Speech of Evans, but says he shall vote for the Resolutions— The orders of the day were called for, at the expiration of the hour, but the house refused to pass to them and the debate continued till past 3 when the house adjourned over to Saturday.
[symbols] Thursday 25. Decr— Christmas— Mr and Mrs. Frye and W. S. Smith dined with us— Magic Lanthern—
Friday. 26. Fall of Snow in the Night— Walk round the Capitol— Visit from Persico—Bust of the President— His Italian Pictures.
Coll. Thomas a morning visitor.
Robert T. Lytle of Ohio, took his Seat; and was sworn, as a member to fill the place vacated by his own resignation.

Bynum of North-Carolina offered a Resolution calling on the Executive for information in relation to the relative positions of the province of Texas, and the Government of the United States; and the progress made towards running the boundary line according to the Treaty of 22d. Feby 1819

L. Lincoln’s Resolution to call on the President for information of the State of the Negotiation with the British Government, respecting the North-eastern boundary, was taken up— Parks made a short reply to the Speeches of Lincoln and of Foster of Georgia on Wednesday—
Ransom H. Gillet of New-York moved to lay the Resolution on the Table—which was rejected by yeas and nays 77 to 79

Grennell asked for the yeas and nays upon the Resolution was adopted. 87 to 79— The members from Virginia generally and Evans—Hall—Mason and Smith of Maine voted for the Resolution— The New York Phalanx all against it—

The Speaker presented a Report from the Secretary of the Treasury with his correspondence with the President of the U.S. Bank respecting the Branch Drafts— Hubbard moved that 10000 copies extra be printed.— lies over to Monday.
Several other Reports from the Executive Departments were presented by the Speaker, and laid on the table

Message from the President, with Report from the Secretary of State, and the Correspondence with the French Government respecting the refusal of the Chamber of deputies to appropriate for the payment of 25 millions of franks stipulated by the Treaty of 4. July 1831—referred to the Committee of Foreign Relations—and 10000 copies to be printed.
Adjourned at 2.— Library—and went with Persico, and saw his Bust of the President and his Pictures.
Monday 29. Decr. 1834— VI.— Deep Snow.
Rode with Albert in a Sleigh to the Capitol
Jarvis from the Committee of Foreign Relations reported two Bills—one to carry into effect the Convention between the U.S. and Spain

Resolution offered last Wednesday by Reynolds of Illinois that in all future elections by the House of Officers, the votes shall be given viva voce—postponed at the motion of Reynolds untill Tuesday 5. Jany.
Bynum, moved that the Resolution offered yesterday by him concerning the province of Texas, and the boundary of Mexico, be laid on the Table—carried Sevier of Arkansas non obstante
10000 copies of the Report of the Secretary of the Treasury, and correspondence with the President US. Bank to be printed.
Ward moves that the military Committee inquire into the expediency of allowing General Leavenworth’s widow his pay to the end of the year.
Dickson moves that the Committee of Manufactures inquire into the expediency of extending to books printed before 1814 the duties now levied on books printed before 1775—

Sevier of Arkansas, moves a Resolution, that the President be requested to negotiate with Spain for her right and title to the Country lying between the Sabine and Red rivers in the Arkansas Territory.
Pinckney moves that the bill establishing a Navy-Yard at Charleston S.C. be made the order of the day for Wednesday 6. Jany.
Letters from the Secy of the Treasury with Documents relating to the claim of U.S. on the Bank of Columbia—
Also the Official proceedings of the Government Directors of the U.S. Bank— Also relating to the Bridge across the Potomac

The Bill for regulating the pay of naval Officers; further debated in the House, as reported from the Committee of the whole by Hubbard, Fillmore, Watmough, M’Kinley, Vanderpoel, Reed, Mann of New-York, Wayne, Mason of Virginia, Brown and Harper of Pennsylvania—no decision
Hubbard moves that the Ladies be admitted to the privileged Seats on Wednesday—carried— Adjourned at 3.
Deep Snow—rode to and from the Capitol—Jarvis home with me
Pinckney of S.C. his call on the Secretary of War, for the causes of the suspensions of the work at Fort Sumpters in Charleston harbour moved yesterday was adopted

Sevier’s Resolution to request the President to negotiate with Spain, for the Country lying between the Sabine and Red rivers was about to pass without opposition when I made objection to it—as an extraordinary call to negotiate with Spain for territory on this Continent where Spain for many years has had no right to any territory— I moved to lay the Resolution on the table— Sevier replied and persisted in asking a vote upon his motion. Polk objected to the Resolution, on the ground that the House have no right to interfere with the President’s power to negotiate, and moves to lay on the table— Cambreleng asks Polk to withdraw his motion; and that the Resolution should be directly met by the House and rejected. Polk accordingly withdraws his motion— Archer makes a warm Speech against the Resolution— Mercer calls upon Sevier to withdraw his Resolution or says he shall be obliged to ask the yeas and nays; he thinks it not sufficient that it should be rejected— Sevier complains of fire from all quartiers of the house and withdraws his Resolution.
Thomas of Maryland, moves an amendment of the 13th. Rule to admit U.S. District Attorneys on the floor of the House—lies one day.

Amendments adopted in Committee of the whole to the Bill regulating the pay of the navy Officers, debated in the House— Fillmore, Miner, Watmough, Bates, Harper of Pennsylvania, M’Kinley, Hardin, Wise, Briggs, Cambreleng, M’Kennan and Anthony, Jarvis and Binney, discuss the Amendments— Wayne, Parker, Mann of New-York, Mason of Virginia, and R. M. Johnson take also part in the debate till past 3. O’Clock, when the house adjourned— Part of the Amendments of the Committee of the whole, were agreed to, and others rejected—further amendments were also proposed, but all rejected—as was the Amendment changing the rule of distribution of prize-money.
Snow yet unbeatin— Rode to and from the Capitol—

The house was called to order as usual at 12 O’Clock— The journal of yesterday was read— At a quarter past twelve, I accompanied the members of the joint Committee of Arrangements on the part of the House— Hubbardto the Senate chamber, where Seats had been assigned to us at the right hand of the Vice-President’s Chair— The President of the United States, with the Secretaries of State, Treasury, War, and Navy, the Postmaster General and Attorney General, and took Seats in front of the Secretary’s Table— At half past 12. we proceeded to the House of Representatives—first the Committee of Arrangements of both houses, whom I followed—then the Senate preceded by their President— Then the President of the United States and Heads of Departments— I took the Speaker’s Chair which he left for the purpose, and I delivered an Oration upon the Life and character of La Fayette—which occupied two hours and fifty minutes— The house and galleries were crowded, many Ladies in the Seats of the members on the floor—immediately after closing, I left the Speaker’s Chair which he resumed, and the House adjourned over to Friday.— The President and Heads of Department, and the members of the Senate immediately withdrew. My voice held out far beyond my expectation— Many of the members greeted me with congratulation— I came home relieved from great anxiety— W. S. Smith called to see us just before we dined— He had heard only part of my discourse— I felt not much exhaustion, immediately after speaking, but in the evening an irresistible Spirit of idleness came over me, and I could neither read nor write.
